Carrageenan"}, "webPages": {"webSearchUrl": "https:\/\/www.bing.com\/search?q=Which+of+these+common+food+additives+comes+from+the+ocean%3f+Carrageenan", "totalEstimatedMatches": 341000, "value": [{"id": "https:\/\/api.cognitive.microsoft.com\/api\/v7\/#WebPages.0", "name": "Carrageenan - Wikipedia", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Carrageenan", "about": [{"name": "Carrageenan"}, {"name": "Carrageenan"}], "isFamilyFriendly": true, "displayUrl": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Carrageenan", "snippet": "These grow from the sea surface to a depth of about 2 metres. The seaweed is normally grown on nylon lines strung between bamboo floats, and it is harvested after ...", "deepLinks": [{"name": "Properties", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Carrageenan#Properties", "snippet": "Carrageenans are large, highly flexible molecules that curl forming helical structures. This gives them the ability to form a variety of different gels at room temperature. They are widely used in the food and other industries as thickening and stabilizing agents. All carrageenans are high-molecular-weight polysaccharides made up of repeating galactose units and 3,6 anhydrogalactose, both sulfated and nonsulfated.
